entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Add Remaining Predefined Color Spaces as Interpolation Spaces
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Add Remaining Predefined Color Spaces as Interpolation Spaces
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Add+Remaining+Predefined+Color+Spaces+as+Interpolation+Spaces%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Add Remaining Predefined Color Spaces as Interpolation Spaces</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Aaron+Krajeski%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Aaron Krajeski' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250224" rel="nofollow">Mon, 24 Feb 2025 06:36:50 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails aaro...@chromium.org
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/blog/css-color-module-level-4/">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/blog/css-color-module-level-4/</a> Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#predefined">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#predefined</a></pre><pre>
Summary
Display P3, Rec2020, ProPhoto RGB and a98 RGB are specified in CSS color 4 as predefined color spaces but had not yet been implemented as color spaces for interpolation. Other UAs have already implemented.
Blink component Blink>CSS <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
*Gecko*: Already implemented. See <a rel="nofollow" href="https://codepen.io/mysterydate/pen/azbzvqB">https://codepen.io/mysterydate/pen/azbzvqB</a> in Firefox.
*WebKit*: Already implemented. See <a rel="nofollow" href="https://codepen.io/mysterydate/pen/azbzvqB">https://codepen.io/mysterydate/pen/azbzvqB</a> in Safari.
*Web developers*: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/382086298">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/382086298</a>
*Other signals*:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ? Yes <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/240b357348202856b077417a3ebf944301776a89/css/css-images/gradient/gradient-eval-predefined-color-spaces.html#L4">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/240b357348202856b077417a3ebf944301776a89/css/css-images/gradient/gradient-eval-predefined-color-spaces.html#L4</a>>
Flag name on about://flags None
Finch feature name None
Non-finch justification None
Requires code in //chrome? False
Estimated milestones
M134
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). None
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5350873536135168?gate=5081273527435264">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5350873536135168?gate=5081273527435264</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/">https://chromestatus.com/</a>>.
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/d1e3e07b-ac7b-449f-b9b9-dc91d515ee6fn%40chromium.org">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/d1e3e07b-ac7b-449f-b9b9-dc91d515ee6fn%40chromium.org</a>. </pre>
</div>

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: highlightsFromPoint API
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: highlightsFromPoint API
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+highlightsFromPoint+API%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: highlightsFromPoint API</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Fernando+Fiori%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Fernando Fiori' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250224" rel="nofollow">Mon, 24 Feb 2025 12:56:25 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Hi all, thanks for the feedback.
@Stephen, thanks for the target milestone suggestion, I just changed it.</pre><pre>
@Robert, I'll respond inline:
*"Ah, I put together a test page with some examples and I see that in fact we only return the highlights if they were not obscured. This wasn't clear to me from the spec, especially as the analogous API elementsFromPoint returns all elements, even those obscured.*
*It might make sense to have a unified API for hit test results that could return a combination of highlights and elements. E.g. if we had options for elementsFromPoint to also return highlights, to include elements with pointer-events: none, to stop at the first hit testing opaque element, etc."*
Custom highlights are supposed to be annotations on top of content, the use cases are about highlights that are visible, so the way I see it, it should return the ones that are not obscured. For example, for spellcheck annotations you wouldn't expect the highlights to react to you hovering over them if there's another element on top (like in your test page for instance). I'm filing an issue in CSSWG about this to define if it should include highlights that are obscured or not and will be updating the spec.
Regards this API also returning elements, I think it doesn't fit the use cases either, we could think about the same example I gave above.
*"Also, as was discussed in the linked issue, using event handlers would be the ideal way I think for developers to handle this."*
For this kind of solution there's been some discussion previously with the CSSWG as well and I wrote some explanation in the explainer for highlightsFromPoint <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/ffiori/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/master/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md#event-based-api">https://github.com/ffiori/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/master/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md#event-based-api</a>> . Summarizing, all the event-based options analyzed carried significant complexity. This API was selected since it is much simpler to implement and still satisfies the use cases proposed adequately. Setting an event listener on some user action to get them (as you did in your sample page) is a good way for developers to use it (see also the example in the spec <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-highlight-api-1/#highlights-from-point-ex">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-highlight-api-1/#highlights-from-point-ex</a>>).
Please let me know if you've got any further questions or concerns.
Thanks, Fernando
El miércoles, 19 de febrero de 2025 a la(s) 6:44:58 a.m. UTC-8, Robert Flack escribió:
Ah, I put together a test page <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://codepen.io/flackr/pen/MYWKQPv">https://codepen.io/flackr/pen/MYWKQPv</a>> with some examples and I see that in fact we only return the highlights if they were not obscured. This wasn't clear to me from the spec, especially as the analogous API elementsFromPoint returns all elements, even those obscured.
It might make sense to have a unified API for hit test results that could return a combination of highlights and elements. E.g. if we had options for elementsFromPoint to also return highlights, to include elements with pointer-events: none, to stop at the first hit testing opaque element, etc.
Also, as was discussed in the linked issue, using event handlers would be the ideal way I think for developers to handle this.
On Wed, Feb 19, 2025 at 8:56 AM Robert Flack <fla...@chromium.org> wrote:
When you add a click handler to get the highlights from a given point and interact with the highlight, how can you tell whether the returned highlight is topmost and should be handled? E.g. how can you tell that there's not a dialog element or some other absolute positioned element painted overtop of the highlight (and highlighted content)?
On Saturday, February 15, 2025 at 9:17:17 AM UTC-5 Stephen Chenney wrote:
I support this as a strongly desired feature for CSS Custom Highlights.
I believe the target milestone should be M-135 given M-134 is in Beta already for a week.
It's also worth pointing out that this method only returns custom highlights, not selection or spelling or any other highlight pseudos. Furthermore, the highlights returned are all from the highlight registry specific to a given realm. Hence it does not expose any information not already known to the script (because script created the highlights in the first place).
Stephen.
On Fri, Feb 14, 2025 at 7:59 PM 'Fernando Fiori' via blink-dev < blin...@chromium.org> wrote:
*Contact emails*
stephan...@microsoft.com, sa...@microsoft.com, ffi...@microsoft.com
*Explainer*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/main/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md">https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/main/highlight/HighlightsFromPointsExplainer.md</a>
*Specification*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-highlight-api-1/#interactions">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-highlight-api-1/#interactions</a>
*Summary*
The highlightsFromPoint API enables developers to interact with custom highlights by detecting which highlights exist at a specific point within a document. This interactivity is valuable for complex web features where multiple highlights may overlap or exist within shadow DOM. By providing precise point-based highlight detection, the API empowers developers to manage dynamic interactions with custom highlights more effectively, such as responding to user clicks or hover events on highlighted regions to trigger custom tooltips, context menus, or other interactive features.
*Blink component*
Blink>CSS <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
*TAG review*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1043">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1043</a>
*TAG review status*
Issues addressed
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility*
The 'highlightsFromPoint' API is a new feature so there isn’t a compatibility risk. The interoperability risk is limited to the usual risk of limited adoption and/or inconsistent browser support for a new feature.
*Gecko*: No signal ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1068">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1068</a>)
*WebKit*: No signal ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/394">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/394</a>)
*Web developers*: Positive ( <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7513#issuecomment-1211033472">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7513#issuecomment-1211033472</a>, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7447#issuecomment-2386160133">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7447#issuecomment-2386160133</a>, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7447#issuecomment-1183422904">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/7447#issuecomment-1183422904</a>)
*Other signals*:
*Ergonomics*
None
*Activation*
None
*Security*
None
*WebView application risks*
*Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?*
None
*Debuggability*
None
*Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?*
Yes
*Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?*
Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-highlight-api/HighlightRegistry-highlightsFromPoint.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-highlight-api/HighlightRegistry-highlightsFromPoint.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/shadow-dom/HighlightRegistry-highlightsFromPoint.html?label=master&label=experimental&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/shadow-dom/HighlightRegistry-highlightsFromPoint.html?label=master&label=experimental&aligned</a>
Note that these tests are currently failing in wpt.fyi because the feature still has the status test in code <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/runtime_enabled_features.json5;l=2333?q=runtime_enabled_features.json&ss=chromium%2Fchromium%2Fsrc">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/runtime_enabled_features.json5;l=2333?q=runtime_enabled_features.json&ss=chromium%2Fchromium%2Fsrc</a>>,
so it’s not activated for these tests that run under experimental flag, but worth mentioning they’re passing in chromium CI. They’re expected to pass in wpt.fyi as well once the feature status is upgraded.
*Flag name on about://flags*
None
*Finch feature name*
HighlightsFromPoint
*Requires code in //chrome?*
False
*Tracking bug*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/365046212">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/365046212</a>
*Estimated milestones*
Shipping on desktop
134
*Anticipated spec changes*
*Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).*
None
*Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/4552801607483392?gate=4762112543686656">https://chromestatus.com/feature/4552801607483392?gate=4762112543686656</a>
*Links to previous Intent discussions*
Intent to Prototype: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/SJ0PR00MB130193097BB3B418C676D88CEC642%40SJ0PR00MB1301.namprd00.prod.outlook.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/SJ0PR00MB130193097BB3B418C676D88CEC642%40SJ0PR00MB1301.namprd00.prod.outlook.com</a>

entry.title: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Fire error event instead of throwing for CSP blocked worker
entry.summary: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Fire error event instead of throwing for CSP blocked worker

entry.title: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Fire error event instead of throwing for CSP blocked worker
entry.summary: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Fire error event instead of throwing for CSP blocked worker
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Fire+error+event+instead+of+throwing+for+CSP+blocked+worker%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Fire error event instead of throwing for CSP blocked worker</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250224" rel="nofollow">Mon, 24 Feb 2025 13:04:01 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>Thanks - it is indeed confusing to follow all the various points in this </tt><tt>thread (sorry if I made it more so). </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On 2/24/25 4:00 PM, 'Liang Zhao' via blink-dev wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>There seems to be something that requires clarification. This feature </tt><tt>only tries to change behavior for CSP blocked worker. "new worker" </tt><tt>could also be blocked due to other reasons like cross origin, and we </tt><tt>are not trying to change behavior of that scenario. </tt><tt>Among the sites that were broken, only apple.com was due to CSP </tt><tt>blocked worker. Other sites were due to cross origin worker url. </tt><tt><a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1471805 and">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1471805 and</a> related code </tt><tt>change (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://phabricator.services.mozilla.com/D188592">https://phabricator.services.mozilla.com/D188592</a>) that is </tt><tt>still open is for the cross origin case. There was an attempt to also </tt><tt>address CSP blocked worker in the same change, but that has not </tt><tt>happened. From the code review comment, it seems that it is not easy </tt><tt>for Mozilla to also handle CSP case. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre></pre><tt>Appreciate the advice on telemetry data collection, will collect a </tt><tt>usage count when "new worker" is blocked by CSP. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Monday, February 24, 2025 at 7:27:50 AM UTC-8 Mike Taylor wrote:
Hey Liang,
Thank you very much for chasing down some answers!
The situation is still a little tricky to evaluate, perhaps because there are conflicting statements across a number of Bugzilla bugs and GitHub issues.
Here's a summary of my understanding:
WebKit states concerns about webcompat (which I share, based on the number of bug reports Firefox has seen):
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/855#issuecomment-2612231865">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/855#issuecomment-2612231865</a>
Interop 2025 accepted the proposal, so presumably Firefox agrees (and you already stated as much). But <a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1471805">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1471805</a> (the patch for Gecko to match Blink/WebKit) is still open with no updates pointing to Interop 2025 or similar.
On the breakage we're aware of:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1912873">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1912873</a> is still open (it should probably be closed as incomplete because the site was updated to remove the problematic video in question - unclear if Apple actually fixed the CSP issue?)
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/webcompat/web-bugs/issues/100874#issuecomment-1615265834">https://github.com/webcompat/web-bugs/issues/100874#issuecomment-1615265834</a> talks about chase.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://chase.com">http://chase.com</a>> breakage, due to an embedded Google Map expecting the error. I tried to load that site to verify today, but it seems like it no longer exists. There's also a different site called "exploretock.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://exploretock.com">http://exploretock.com</a>>" which was broken in Firefox, maybe fixed now?
If anyone from Mozilla is reading, it would be cool if someone went and cleaned up a bunch of bugs so the situation was less confusing.
(some comments below)
On 2/21/25 1:29 PM, 'Liang Zhao' via blink-dev wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> An update for the question on Mozilla coordination. Mozilla has not changed their behavior and does not plan to do so. They actually filed an interop issue at <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/855">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/855</a>, which was discussed at interop 2025. My understanding of that discussion is that Chrome and Safari should change the behavior to align with spec, and revert to current behavior if we have to due to site compat. There are actually other cases where Mozilla fire error event while Chrome and Safari throw exception, like not same origin worker url. Most of the cases in
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/issues/41745#issuecomment-2377512723">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/issues/41745#issuecomment-2377512723</a>, <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/webcompat/web-bugs/issues/100874 and">https://github.com/webcompat/web-bugs/issues/100874 and</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1927467">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1927467</a> are for those cases. We are not trying to change behavior for those cases with this feature. The support.apple.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://support.apple.com">http://support.apple.com</a>> issue is related to CSP blocked worker. The site has been updated and doesn't have the issue any more.
On Wednesday, January 22, 2025 at 1:20:52 AM UTC-8 Mike Taylor wrote:
In
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/issues/41745#issuecomment-2377512723">https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/issues/41745#issuecomment-2377512723</a> - there's discussion of breakage on support.apple.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://support.apple.com">http://support.apple.com</a>> with this behavior, and Firefox developers mentions moving their behavior to align with Safari/Webkit given this breakage. The Bugzilla issue links to <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/webcompat/web-bugs/issues/100874">https://github.com/webcompat/web-bugs/issues/100874</a> and <a rel="nofollow" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1927467">https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1927467</a>.
Have you coordinated with Mozilla on this?
On 1/21/25 7:50 PM, 'Liang Zhao' via blink-dev wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On Monday, January 20, 2025 at 4:48:38 AM UTC-8 Mike Taylor wrote:
I'd still like to better understand the compat risk here - I suspect it's low, but I would not be surprised if there is code attempting to handle the difference between Chrome/Safari & Firefox with UA sniffing (which means it may break after this change).
Have you tried to look at any usage in the wild, to get a sense of how sites are dealing with CSP blocking a worker today?
The expected way to handle CSP blocking is to update CSP policy to allow the worker. Normally, a site’s own content security policy should not block its own workers. If a worker is blocked, the worker would not run and part of the site would be broken. The developer should update the site’s CSP policy to allow the worker. DevTools console message would clearly state that the worker is blocked by the site’s own CSP and CSP reporting feature allows site to detect the blocking of workers in the wild. Whether a worker runs should be more important to a site than the behavior when the worker is blocked. If a site cares about the blocking, it is expected that the site either updates its CSP to allow the worker, or removes the worker related code if the worker should not run. This is the main reason of my assessment of low compat risk. It is a behavior change when an error of a site's configuration has already caused bigger issue to the site. </pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> I hear you, but if we change the behavior my concern is about the user's experience. Waiting for devs to notice and fix the breakage is not ideal. </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> I thought about collecting telemetry data and decided not to. We could collect counts of worker being blocked by CSP, but it would be hard to collect data on how a site might handle the blocking, like whether a site sniffs UA string and behaves differently, has a try-catch or has code to handle error event later if we don’t throw exception in constructor. As it is expected that it could happen that CSP blocks some workers, like during testing of a site, a raw count of the blocking would not help much on measuring the impact of this behavior change. </pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Having some kind of telemetry would help here, even if imperfect. If we know at least 3 sites were broken in Firefox for years (apple.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://apple.com">http://apple.com</a>>, dining.chase.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://dining.chase.com">http://dining.chase.com</a>>, exploretock.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="http://exploretock.com">http://exploretock.com</a>>), it seems safe to assume there is more we don't know about.
</pre><tt>Will add telemetry data collection to collect a usage count when "new </tt><tt>worker" is blocked by CSP. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> On 1/17/25 7:27 PM, Liang Zhao (REDMOND) wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Got positive signal from Safari.
On Wednesday, January 15, 2025 at 5:25:48 PM UTC+1 Chris Harrelson wrote:
Please also fill out the various reviews in your chromestatus entry (privacy, security, enterprise, debuggability, testing).
On Tue, Jan 14, 2025 at 2:43 PM 'Liang Zhao (REDMOND)' via blink-dev <blin...@chromium.org> wrote:
*From:*Mike Taylor <mike...@chromium.org> *Sent:* Tuesday, January 14, 2025 7:10 AM *To:* Liang Zhao (REDMOND) <liang...@microsoft.com>; blin...@chromium.org *Cc:* hiro...@chromium.org; mk...@chromium.org *Subject:* [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Fire error event instead of throwing for CSP blocked worker
You don't often get email from mike...@chromium.org. Learn why this is important <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification">https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification</a>>
On 1/13/25 5:19 PM, 'Liang Zhao (REDMOND)' via blink-dev wrote:
*Contact emails*
lz...@microsoft.com
*Explainer*
None
I think an explainer (or even an inline text explaining the change, providing an example, etc) would have significantly helped folks understand what it is that you're trying to ship.
Could you write something to that effect?
When the url is blocked by Content Security Policy, script code “new Worker(url)” and “new SharedWorker(url)” currently throws exception. According to spec, the CSP check is done as part of fetch which happens asynchronously and the constructor should not throw. Instead an error event should fire after the object is returned.
This feature aligns Chromium behavior with spec.
*Specification*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-main-fetch">https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-main-fetch</a>
This points at a relatively long algorithm. Can you point out the specific steps that are relevant here?
Step 7 of the linked “main fetch” section. Updated the spec link in chromestatus to <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/CSP3/#fetch-integration">https://www.w3.org/TR/CSP3/#fetch-integration</a>, which is a better place to understand that CSP check is part of fetch instead of details of how fetch is done in the fetch spec.
*Summary*
When blocked by CSP, Chromium currently throws SecurityError from constructor. Spec requires CSP to be checked as part of fetch and fires error event asynchronously. This aims to make Chromium spec conformant, which is not throwing during constructor and fires error event asynchronously.
Which constructor?
The constructor of Worker and SharedWorker objects. Also updated the chromestatus so that it is clear.
An example demonstrating where developers need to catch those exceptions now would be helpful IMO.
Before the change if developer wants to handle the worker being blocked failure, the code would be something like this:
try {
var worker = new Worker(url);
…
} catch (e) {
// error handling code
}
After the change, the code would be something like this:
var worker = new Worker(url);
worker.addEventListener('error', function(event) {
// error handling code
});
…
*Blink component*
Blink>SecurityFeature>ContentSecurityPolicy
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ESecurityFeature%3EContentSecurityPolicy%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ESecurityFeature%3EContentSecurityPolicy%22</a>>
*TAG review*
None
*TAG review status*
Not applicable
*Risks*
*Interoperability and Compatibility*
Are you able to expand on the compatibility implications for this change, i.e., do we know if Firefox has any site breakage as a result of their behavior? What scenarios might surprise developers who are relying on Chrome's current behavior, etc?
We are not aware of any site breakage for Firefox due to its behavior. If a site has a worker that is blocked by CSP and has code after "new Worker()", those code currently does not run in Chrome or Safari, but runs in Firefox. After the change, those code would run in Chrome.
Also, if sites are doing something as a result of catching a CSP failure exception, that would stop working (unless they shift to start listening to the relevant event), right?
That is correct. If a site has code that runs upon catching SecurityError exception during new Worker()/SharedWorker(), those code would not run. Instead. if the site has error event listener, that event listener will run.
Currently Firefox works as spec-ed while Safari works the same as Chrome. With the wrong test code in WPT tests, Firefox is failing the tests:
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/dedicated-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/dedicated-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/dedicated-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/dedicated-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/shared-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/shared-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/shared-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/shared-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>> After updating Chrome code and WPT tests, Firefox passes the tests while Safari fails the tests.
Can you explain what you mean by wrong test code?
The current WPT test code expects exception to throw, which is not what’s required by the spec. The test code has a TODO comment states that the test code is wrong with a link to <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/663298">https://crbug.com/663298</a>,
/Gecko/: Shipped/Shipping
/WebKit/: No signal
Have we asked for a signal from WebKit folks?
Filed an issue at <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/451">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/451</a>.
Positive signal from <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/451:">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/451:</a> “As such I suggest we mark this as position: support one week from now.”
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/: This changes the behavior the same as Firefox.
*WebView application risks*
/Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?/
*Debuggability*
When worker is blocked by CSP, there is DevTools message logged about the blocking by CSP. This behavior is not changed.
*Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?*
Yes
*Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?*
Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/dedicated-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/dedicated-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/dedicated-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/dedicated-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/shared-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/shared-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/shared-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/content-security-policy/worker-src/shared-worker-src-child-fallback-blocked.sub.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>> Note that the test code currently has the wrong expectation and will be updated as part of this feature work.
*Flag name on about://flags*
None
*Finch feature name*
None
*Non-finch justification*
This is a simple change of behavior for uncommon scenario where worker is blocked by CSP, and the changed behavior is the same as Firefox and spec aligned. It is unlikely that a site depends on the current behavior of throwing exception for blocked worker.
Can we back up "it is unlikely" with some data? Absent that, I would strongly suggest we put this behind a flag.
Changed the plan to put this new behavior behind NoThrowForCSPBlockedWorker feature flag. Also updated the chromestatus.
*Requires code in //chrome?*
False
*Tracking bug*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41285169">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41285169</a>
*Estimated milestones*
Shipping on desktop
134
DevTrial on desktop
134
Shipping on Android
134
DevTrial on Android
134
Shipping on WebView
134
*Anticipated spec changes*
/Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way)./
None
*Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status*
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5177205656911872?gate=5108732671033344">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5177205656911872?gate=5108732671033344</a>
</pre><tt> -- </tt><tt> You received this message because you are </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"> subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+...@chromium.org. To view this discussion visit
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CO1PR00MB2285E0FC0FEC6768415E9F979E1F2%40CO1PR00MB2285.namprd00.prod.outlook.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CO1PR00MB2285E0FC0FEC6768415E9F979E1F2%40CO1PR00MB2285.namprd00.prod.outlook.com</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CO1PR00MB2285E0FC0FEC6768415E9F979E1F2%40CO1PR00MB2285.namprd00.prod.outlook.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CO1PR00MB2285E0FC0FEC6768415E9F979E1F2%40CO1PR00MB2285.namprd00.prod.outlook.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer</a>>.
</pre><tt> -- </tt><tt> You received this message because you are </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"> subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+...@chromium.org.
To view this discussion visit
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/BY1PR00MB2289751B22915D40E547832F9E182%40BY1PR00MB2289.namprd00.prod.outlook.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/BY1PR00MB2289751B22915D40E547832F9E182%40BY1PR00MB2289.namprd00.prod.outlook.com</a>

</pre></blockquote><tt> -- </tt><tt> You received this message because you are subscribed to the </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+...@chromium.org. To view this discussion visit

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS Custom Functions (@function)
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS Custom Functions (@function)
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+CSS+Custom+Functions+%5C%28%40function%5C%29%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS Custom Functions (@function)</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Anders+Hartvoll+Ruud%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Anders Hartvoll Ruud</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250225" rel="nofollow">Tue, 25 Feb 2025 04:26:13 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails
andr...@chromium.org, se...@chromium.org</pre><pre>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://css.oddbird.net/sasslike/mixins-functions">https://css.oddbird.net/sasslike/mixins-functions</a>
Note: the explainer includes a description of mixins as well. This intent covers custom functions (@function) only.
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-mixins-1">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-mixins-1</a>
Note: despite its shortname (css-mixins), the spec currently describes custom functions only.
Summary
Custom Functions are similar to custom properties <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-variables">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-variables</a>>, but instead of returning a single fixed value, it returns a value based on other custom properties, parameters, and conditionals.
Example: Custom light-dark function:
@function --light-dark(--light, --dark) {
result: var(--light);
@media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) {
result: var(--dark);
}
}
div {
background-image: --light-dark(black-logo.png, white-logo.png);
}
Blink component
Blink>CSS <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
TAG review
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1031">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1031</a>
TAG review status
Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
Gecko: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1148">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1148</a> )
WebKit: No signal (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/437">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/437</a>)
Web developers: Positive
(Dug up what I could find per goo.gle/developer-signals):
-
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://medium.com/css-magic/custom-css-functions-the-next-big-leap-in-styling-5acbd69f5526">https://medium.com/css-magic/custom-css-functions-the-next-big-leap-in-styling-5acbd69f5526</a> -
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://johannesodland.github.io/2024/12/12/web-wish-12-custom-css-functions.html">https://johannesodland.github.io/2024/12/12/web-wish-12-custom-css-functions.html</a> -
“sorely needed functionality for authors”
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1031#issuecomment-2637024845">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1031#issuecomment-2637024845</a>> - LeaVerou <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/LeaVerou">https://github.com/LeaVerou</a>> -
Appeared as a missing feature in State of CSS 2024 <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://2024.stateofcss.com/en-US/usage/#css_missing_features">https://2024.stateofcss.com/en-US/usage/#css_missing_features</a>>.
Other signals:
WebView application risks
None
Debuggability
The Devtools team is working on “basic support” for @function: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/17UCa0XDXAG9EBx18w1fXAA9SL3V9Lr4vTptaXYyE1CA/">https://docs.google.com/document/d/17UCa0XDXAG9EBx18w1fXAA9SL3V9Lr4vTptaXYyE1CA/</a>
Unfortunately that doc requires @google.com to access, but “basic support” primarily means that callsites can be clicked, you’ll be taken to the relevant function, and you’ll be able to edit the contents of the function.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?
Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-mixins">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-mixins</a>
-
at-function-cssom.tentative.html
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-mixins/at-function-cssom.tentative.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-mixins/at-function-cssom.tentative.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>> is marked tentative because the spec is currently missing a few obvious parts from the API. -
The subtest "Indexed property getter" is failing due to a Bindings bug. This is an existing issue (likely low impact) that's unrelated to Custom Functions. crbug.com/333965945 -
dashed-function-cycles.tentative.html
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-mixins/dashed-function-cycles.tentative.html?label=master&label=experimental&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-mixins/dashed-function-cycles.tentative.html?label=master&label=experimental&aligned</a>> is marked tentative because the spec has not yet caught up with the resolution in <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11500">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11500</a>.
In both cases, I’ll make sure we get these things edited so we can remove the .tentative suffixes before shipping.
I do not plan to fix crbug.com/333965945 before shipping, which means that a failure on "Indexed property getter" is to be expected. I will not ship with any other test failures; unexpected red boxes on wpt.fyi may be considered temporary, usually due to Canary not having picked up the latest changes yet.
Flag name on about://flags
CSSFunctions
Finch feature name
CSSFunctions
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/325504770">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/325504770</a>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop
136
Shipping on Android
136
Shipping on WebView
136
Anticipated spec changes
At this point, I anticipate only one real spec change: disallowing argument values that begin with two dashes (‘--’). This is to make #11749 (named arguments) <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11749">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11749</a>> possible in the future without compat concerns.
All other issues are not interesting in terms of compat risk.
Full list (only the top one being interesting):
-
#11749 [css-mixins-1] Named argument passing? <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11749">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11749</a>> -
This can be added later. However, we should reserve space for this in the syntax immediately, to avoid compat issues in the future. Issue 398887938 <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/398887938">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/398887938</a>> tracks this. -
#10558 [css-mixins] <dashed-function> syntax seems invalid <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10558">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10558</a>> -
Editorial issue. The commenter seems satisfied now: “So this issue may therefore be considered fixed” <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10558#issuecomment-2255746650">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10558#issuecomment-2255746650</a>> . -
#10006 [css-mixins] Allow mixins/functions to be called via custom properties <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10006">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10006</a>> -
We can choose to add this later; it does not affect the API shipping now. -
#9992 Proposal: CSS Variable Groups <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9992">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9992</a>> -
Same as the previous issue. -
#9990 [css-values][css-variables][css-mixins] Generic fallback syntax for IACVT values <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9990">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9990</a>> -
Same as the previous issue. -
#10222 [css-mixins] Proposal: @like rule for repurposing page default styles <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10222">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10222</a>> -
Unrelated to CSS Functions. (Marked css-mixins since it has conceptual similarities with mixins.) -
#11500 [css-values] Short-circuit if() evaluation <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11500">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11500</a>> -
Resolved, just needs a spec edit. -
#11455 [css-values-5][css-mixins-1] Add an if-test for local variables <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11455">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11455</a>> -
Same as the previous issue. -
#11190 [css-functions-mixins] Handling superfluous arguments <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11190">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/11190</a>> -
Same as the previous issue. -
#10562 [css-mixins] Should result be mandatory in @function? <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10562">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10562</a>> -
Same as the previous issue. -
#9350 Proposal: Custom CSS Functions & Mixins <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9350">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9350</a>> -
Same as the previous issue.
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5179721933651968?gate=5074532782309376">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5179721933651968?gate=5074532782309376</a>
Links to previous Intent discussions
Intent to Prototype: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/b-BTxKD-Ldc/m/1pyobjq7AQAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/b-BTxKD-Ldc/m/1pyobjq7AQAJ</a>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Timestamps for RTC Encoded Frames
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Timestamps for RTC Encoded Frames
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Timestamps+for+RTC+Encoded+Frames%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Timestamps for RTC Encoded Frames</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250225" rel="nofollow">Tue, 25 Feb 2025 05:28:48 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails gui...@chromium.org </pre><pre>
Explainer <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/guidou/webrtc-encoded-transform/blob/master/timestamps.md">https://github.com/guidou/webrtc-encoded-transform/blob/master/timestamps.md</a>
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-encoded-transform/#dom-rtcencodedaudioframemetadata-receivetime">https://w3c.github.io/webrtc-encoded-transform/#dom-rtcencodedaudioframemetadata-receivetime</a>
Summary
This feature consists in exposing to the Web some timestamps that are present in WebRTC encoded frames transmitted via RTCPeerConnection. The timestamps in question are: -Capture timestamp: the timestamp when a frame was originally captured -Receive timestamp: the timestamp when a frame was received
Blink component Blink>WebRTC
TAG review <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1049">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1049</a>
TAG review status Pending
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Interoperability risk: The main risk is that other browser do not implement this change. However, this change has the support of other major browsers and it is small enough that it should not be difficult to support. Compatibility risk: No compatibility risk as the change is strictly additive.
Gecko: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-encoded-transform/pull/240">https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-encoded-transform/pull/240</a>) No position requested at <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions</a> since this is a minor addition to an existing spec. Linked to PRs instead (merged into spec or "editors can integrate").
WebKit: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-encoded-transform/pull/237">https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-encoded-transform/pull/237</a>) No position requested at <a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/</a> since this is a minor addition to an existing spec. Linked to PRs instead (merged into spec or "editors can integrate").
Web developers: Positive (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-encoded-transform/issues/225">https://github.com/w3c/webrtc-encoded-transform/issues/225</a>)
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
N/A
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/webrtc-encoded-transform/tentative/RTCEncodedFrame-timestamps.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/webrtc-encoded-transform/tentative/RTCEncodedFrame-timestamps.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>
Flag name on about://flags None
Finch feature name None
Non-finch justification None
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://crbug.com/391114797">https://crbug.com/391114797</a>
Availability expectation Feature is available in Chromium in the short term, and eventually available in other browsers.
Adoption expectation Feature is used by multiple partners to provide functionality within 12 months of launch in Chrome.
Non-OSS dependencies
Does the feature depend on any code or APIs outside the Chromium open source repository and its open-source dependencies to function? N/A
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 135
Shipping on Android 135
Shipping on WebView 135
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). None
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/6294486420029440?gate=5205778715377664">https://chromestatus.com/feature/6294486420029440?gate=5205778715377664</a>
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status.
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/67bdc57a.2b0a0220.2aae14.02b8.GAE%40google.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/67bdc57a.2b0a0220.2aae14.02b8.GAE%40google.com</a>. </pre>
</div>

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS Sign-Related Functions: abs(), sign()
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS Sign-Related Functions: abs(), sign()
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+CSS+Sign%5C-Related+Functions%5C%3A+abs%5C%28%5C%29%2C+sign%5C%28%5C%29%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: CSS Sign-Related Functions: abs(), sign()</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250225" rel="nofollow">Tue, 25 Feb 2025 07:40:03 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2
On 2/25/25 2:19 AM, Daniel Bratell wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre>
LGTM1
</pre><tt>Would be nice if something could be done about the remaining parts, </tt><tt>but creating interoperability is valuable on its own. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
/Daniel
On 2025-02-19 17:54, Daniil Sakhapov wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>I don't know why we don't support image-resolution property, it seems </tt><tt>like noone does. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>It would make most sense to remove those tests for image-resolution, </tt><tt>and move the tests to a separate file for grid-template-rows. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
среда, 19 февраля 2025 г. в 13:39:36 UTC+1, Yoav Weiss:
Thanks for catching us up here!
On Wednesday, February 19, 2025 at 11:29:12 AM UTC+1 Daniil Sakhapov wrote:
The first 3 tests are for image-resolution property, which we (and others?) don't support.
Why not?
The last 3 tests are for grid-template-rows, which requires also display: grid, and some elements inside the grid, but the person who added the test didn't change HTML, so the test is wrongly expects a value, but in always will be 'none'.
Can we fix the tests?
вторник, 18 февраля 2025 г. в 18:28:55 UTC+1, Mike Taylor:
On 2/18/25 8:28 AM, Chromestatus wrote:
</pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"> Contact emails sakha...@chromium.org
Explainer None
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#sign-funcs">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#sign-funcs</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#sign-funcs">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#sign-funcs</a>>
Summary
The sign-related functions ​abs() and sign() ​compute various functions related to the sign of their argument. The abs(A) function contains one calculation A, and returns the absolute value of A, as the same type as the input: if A’s numeric value is positive or 0⁺, just A again; otherwise -1 * A. The sign(A) function contains one calculation A, and returns -1 if A’s numeric value is negative, +1 if A’s numeric value is positive, 0⁺ if A’s numeric value is 0⁺, and 0⁻ if A’s numeric value is 0⁻. The return type is a <number>, made consistent with the input calculation’s type.
Blink component Blink>CSS
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
/Gecko/: Shipped/Shipping
/WebKit/: Shipped/Shipping
/Web developers/: Strongly positive <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181#comment9">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181#comment9</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181#comment9">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181#comment9</a>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181#comment10">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181#comment10</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181#comment10">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181#comment10</a>>
/Other signals/:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>? Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/signs-abs-computed.html">https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/signs-abs-computed.html</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/signs-abs-computed.html">https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/signs-abs-computed.html</a>>
</pre></blockquote><pre style="margin: 0em;"> I see there's 6 tests near the bottom that all browsers are failing. What's up with that? </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Flag name on about://flags CSSSignRelatedFunctions
Finch feature name None
Non-finch justification None
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40253181</a>>
Estimated milestones Shipping on desktop 135 Shipping on Android 135 Shipping on WebView 135
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
None

entry.title: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Interpolation progress functional notations: CSS *progress() functions
entry.summary: Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Interpolation progress functional notations: CSS *progress() functions
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5BEXTERNAL%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Interpolation+progress+functional+notations%5C%3A+CSS+%5C%2Aprogress%5C%28%5C%29+functions%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Interpolation progress functional notations: CSS *progress() functions</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mike+Taylor%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mike Taylor</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250225" rel="nofollow">Tue, 25 Feb 2025 07:43:31 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<tt>LGTM2, but can you remove inline issue 3 from the spec if it's no longer </tt><tt>relevant? It's confusing otherwise. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
On 2/25/25 2:23 AM, Daniel Bratell wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><pre>
LGTM1
/Daniel
On 2025-02-20 10:15, Daniil Sakhapov wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>The discussion for *progress() functions is finished, with WebKit </tt><tt>already supporting it and Gecko implementing. </tt><tt>The warning is about *mix() functions and the discussion in the issue </tt><tt>is about only them as well. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
среда, 19 февраля 2025 г. в 20:43:15 UTC+1, dan...@microsoft.com:
The spec section <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-values-5/#progress">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-values-5/#progress</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-values-5/#progress">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-values-5/#progress</a>> still has this warning at the top: /“This section is an exploratory draft, and not yet approved by the CSSWG /[Issue #6245] <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6245">https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6245</a>>/”./
//
Scanning through the linked issue I’m unclear on whether that warning still applies or whether the CSSWG resolved at some point on the subset of behavior that’s proposed to ship here. Can you help me understand the degree to which the discussion around these has reached a conclusion? I see that there are still new posts happening in that issue in the past week.
Thanks,
Dan
*From:*'Penelope McLachlan' via blink-dev <blink-dev@chromium.org> *Sent:* Wednesday, February 19, 2025 10:16 AM *To:* Daniel Bratell <bratel...@gmail.com> *Cc:* Daniil Sakhapov <sakha...@chromium.org>; blink-dev <blink-dev@chromium.org>; Mike Taylor <miketa...@chromium.org>; Chromestatus <ad...@cr-status.appspotmail.com <<a rel="nofollow" href="mailto:ad...@cr-status.appspotmail.com">mailto:ad...@cr-status.appspotmail.com</a>>> *Subject:* [EXTERNAL] Re: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Interpolation progress functional notations: CSS *progress() functions
Some other example use cases:
- Trigger layout changes as the user scrolls for storytelling or creative direction e.g. Create gradients that smoothly shift colors or positions based on scroll progress or container size, or apply filter effects like blur or saturation based on scroll position or container dimensions, creating dynamic visual effects.
- Progress bars based on scroll position or container layout
- Adjust font sizes based on the viewport width or container size, for example to improve readability across different screen sizes.
e.g. h1 { font-size: calc(1rem + 2rem * media-progress(width, 320px, 1200px)); }
On Wed, Feb 19, 2025 at 6:44 AM Daniel Bratell <bratel...@gmail.com> wrote:
I also find it a bit hard to understand what it is meant to accomplish and how it does so. I might be missing some basic knowledge block here, but ... why?
Maybe when the tests are updated I can look at those, but if you were to explain this to someone like ... I don't know, a manager, how would you explain what it does?
/Daniel
On 2025-02-19 11:34, Daniil Sakhapov wrote:
I imagine the use case example would be using e.g. container-progress inside color(), so that you can change the color, based on some ancestor parent's size - 'color: rgb(container-progress(width of my-container, var(--container-min-size), var(--container-max-size)), ..., ...);'
Ah, for some reason we don't have 'In Progress' option for Gecko, only for Webkit, and the tool didn't copy my comment on that here, but they are working on it.
The test is failing as there has been minor synax change and it's been addressed on Monday, WPT hasn't been updated yet.
вторник, 18 февраля 2025 г. в 20:24:40 UTC+1, Mike Taylor:
On 2/18/25 12:15 PM, Chromestatus wrote:
Contact emails
sakha...@chromium.org
Explainer
None
Could you describe what these features allow for (beyond what you have in the summary), maybe with some example code? It's not obvious to me what it means practically to represent proportional distance of a container feature, for example.
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-values-5/#progress">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-values-5/#progress</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-values-5/#progress">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-values-5/#progress</a>>
Summary
The progress(), media-progress(), and container-progress() functional notations represent the proportional distance of a given value (the progress value) from one value (the progress start value) to another value (the progress end value). They allow drawing a progress ratio from math functions, media features, and container features, respectively.
Blink component
Blink>CSS
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3ECSS%22</a>>
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
None
/Gecko/: No signal
Can we request one please?
/WebKit/: Shipped/Shipping
/Web developers/: Strongly positive Mostly for calc() hacks like getting rid of units
/Other signals/:
WebView application risks
/Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?/
None
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/progress-computed.tentative.html">https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/progress-computed.tentative.html</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/progress-computed.tentative.html">https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/progress-computed.tentative.html</a>>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/media-progress-computed.tentative.html">https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/media-progress-computed.tentative.html</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/media-progress-computed.tentative.html">https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/media-progress-computed.tentative.html</a>>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/container-progress-computed.tentative.html">https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/container-progress-computed.tentative.html</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/container-progress-computed.tentative.html">https://wpt.fyi/css/css-values/container-progress-computed.tentative.html</a>>
These tests are all failing in Chromium. Any reason why? Also, they shouldn't be considered tentative tests now, correct?
Flag name on about://flags
CSSProgressNotation
Finch feature name
None
Non-finch justification
None
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40944203">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40944203</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40944203">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40944203</a>>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop
135
Shipping on Android
135
Shipping on WebView
135
Anticipated spec changes
/Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way)./
None

<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5112558941634560?gate=5096732792455168">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5112558941634560?gate=5096732792455168</a>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Support rel / relList attributes for SVGAElement
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Support rel / relList attributes for SVGAElement
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Support+rel+%5C%2F+relList+attributes+for+SVGAElement%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Support rel / relList attributes for SVGAElement</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Chromestatus%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Chromestatus</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250226" rel="nofollow">Wed, 26 Feb 2025 08:49:17 -0800</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails dman...@microsoft.com </pre><pre>
Explainer None
Specification <a rel="nofollow" href="https://svgwg.org/svg2-draft/linking.html#__svg__SVGAElement__rel">https://svgwg.org/svg2-draft/linking.html#__svg__SVGAElement__rel</a>
Design docs
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ejVVjucwrfzXSk-W8r5TPMbzk6F25D-eUkD6YInOJFE/edit?tab=t.0">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ejVVjucwrfzXSk-W8r5TPMbzk6F25D-eUkD6YInOJFE/edit?tab=t.0</a>
Summary
The SVGAElement interface in SVG 2.0 allows manipulation of <a> elements similar to HTML anchor elements. Supporting the rel and relList attributes enhances security and privacy for developers. This alignment with HTML anchor elements ensures consistency and ease of use across web technologies.
Blink component Blink>SVG
TAG review None
TAG review status Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
This is already supported in Firefox and Safari
Gecko: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/SVGAElement#browser_compatibility">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/SVGAElement#browser_compatibility</a>)
WebKit: Shipped/Shipping (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://trac.webkit.org/changeset/264789/webkit">https://trac.webkit.org/changeset/264789/webkit</a>)
Web developers: No signals
Other signals:
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
The functionality of the rel and relList attributes is similar to how they operate for HTML <a> elements.
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)? Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests? Yes wpt.fyi links: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/svg/linking/scripted/a.rel-getter-01.svg">https://wpt.fyi/results/svg/linking/scripted/a.rel-getter-01.svg</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/svg/linking/scripted/rellist-feature-detection.svg">https://wpt.fyi/results/svg/linking/scripted/rellist-feature-detection.svg</a> Corresponding Chromium WPTs links: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/svg/linking/scripted/a.rel-getter-01.svg">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/svg/linking/scripted/a.rel-getter-01.svg</a>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/svg/linking/scripted/rellist-feature-detection.svg">https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/svg/linking/scripted/rellist-feature-detection.svg</a>
Flag name on about://flags
Finch feature name SvgAnchorElementRelAttributes
Requires code in //chrome? False
Tracking bug <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40589293">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40589293</a>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop 135
Shipping on Android 135
Shipping on iOS 135
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (eg links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (eg, changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way). None
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5066982694846464?gate=6230229422702592">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5066982694846464?gate=6230229422702592</a>
